skill.name: context-driven-development
skill.description: Use this skill when working with Conductor's context-driven development methodology, managing project context artifacts, or understanding the relationship between product.md, tech-stack.md, and workflow.md files.
skill.summary: Guides structured AI-assisted development through project context documentation and artifacts
skill.author: wshobson

security_audit.summary: Documentation skill describing development methodology. Static scanner false positives: slash commands like /conductor:setup are tool invocation syntax, not code execution. No cryptographic operations, scripts, network requests, or dangerous patterns found in actual content.

content.value_statement: Establish structured project documentation to improve AI consistency and team alignment. Define context artifacts that guide development decisions and maintain institutional memory across sessions.
actual_capabilities: Describes artifact structure for product, tech-stack, workflow, and tracks documentation
Provides guidelines for context maintenance and synchronization
Outlines greenfield and brownfield project setup procedures
Includes context validation checklists and best practices
Defines session continuity patterns for multi-session development
Addresses common anti-patterns in context management
limitations: Documentation only - does not execute code or perform file operations
Requires manual setup of project directory structure
Relies on team discipline to maintain updated context
Cannot validate that code matches documented specifications

use_cases.title: New Team Onboarding
use_cases.description: Team leads use this skill to establish consistent development practices across team members, ensuring everyone has access to the same product vision, technical decisions, and workflow standards.

use_cases.title: AI-Assisted Development Projects
use_cases.description: Developers working with Claude Code or Codex use structured context to improve AI consistency across sessions, reducing the need to re-explain project requirements each time.

use_cases.title: Legacy Codebase Modernization
use_cases.description: Teams working on brownfield projects use this skill to extract implicit context from existing code and establish new documentation standards before refactoring.

prompt_templates.title: Getting Started with Context-Driven Development
prompt_templates.prompt: I'm starting a new project and want to establish proper context management. Can you explain the core artifacts I need to create (product.md, tech-stack.md, workflow.md) and the recommended directory structure? What are the key principles I should follow?

prompt_templates.title: Updating Documentation After Changes
prompt_templates.prompt: I just finished implementing a feature in my Conductor project. Which context artifacts should I update? Specifically, should I modify product.md, tech-stack.md, workflow.md, or tracks.md, and how do I keep them synchronized?

prompt_templates.title: Context Validation Checklist
prompt_templates.prompt: I'm about to start working on a new track. What is the context validation checklist I should run through? What checks should I perform for product context, technical context, workflow context, and track context before proceeding?

prompt_templates.title: Resolving Context Discrepancies
prompt_templates.prompt: I'm finding inconsistencies between my tech-stack.md and the actual code dependencies. What should I do when context artifacts are out of sync? How do I handle the case where my technical documentation doesn't match the implementation?

output_examples.input: I'm onboarding a new developer to our Conductor project and want to ensure they understand the context management approach. What are the essential artifacts and how should they be structured?
output: Review the project's conductor/ directory structure which contains: index.md (navigation hub), product.md (vision and goals), tech-stack.md (technology choices), workflow.md (development practices), and tracks.md (work unit registry)
The new developer should first read product.md to understand what we're building and why, then tech-stack.md to understand our technology choices and dependencies
They should review workflow.md to understand our development methodology, commit conventions, and quality gates before starting work
Finally, have them check tracks.md to see active work and review any specific track's spec.md and plan.md for their assigned tasks

output_examples.input: My team is inconsistent about updating context artifacts after we complete features. Some people update product.md, others update tech-stack.md, and rarely do we keep everything synchronized.
output_examples.output: Establish a consistent update process after every feature completion. When work is done, automatically update: tracks.md to mark status as complete, product.md to reflect new capabilities, and any tech-stack.md changes if new dependencies were introduced. Always verify that related artifacts are updated together to prevent stale documentation.

best_practices: Read all relevant context artifacts before starting any implementation work
Make incremental context changes rather than massive rewrites
Version context changes alongside code changes in git
Include context artifact reviews in pull request processes
Run the context validation checklist before starting major features
anti_patterns: Creating undocumented context artifacts or relying on ad-hoc information
Failing to update context after feature completion or dependency changes
Allowing one person to maintain context without team input or review
Creating excessive detail that makes context difficult to maintain
Treating context as static rather than living documentation that evolves

faq.question: What is context-driven development?
faq.answer: Context-driven development treats project context as a first-class artifact managed alongside code. Instead of relying on ad-hoc prompts or scattered documentation, it establishes persistent, structured documentation that informs all AI interactions and team alignment.

faq.question: Which artifacts should I create for my project?
faq.answer: The core artifacts are product.md (what and why), tech-stack.md (with what), workflow.md (how to work), and tracks.md (what's happening). Additional artifacts like product-guidelines.md can be created for communication standards.

faq.question: How do I know when to update context artifacts?
faq.answer: Update context when product vision changes, new features are added or completed, dependencies are added or upgraded, team practices evolve, or workflow patterns are adopted. Always update related artifacts together to maintain synchronization.

faq.question: Is this skill suitable for greenfield or brownfield projects?
faq.answer: Yes. For greenfield projects, you establish all artifacts from scratch. For brownfield projects, you extract implicit context from existing code and patterns, then establish new standards while preserving working patterns.

faq.question: How does this improve AI-assisted development?
faq.answer: Structured context produces consistent AI behavior across sessions. Instead of re-explaining requirements each time, AI assistants reference documented standards, leading to more predictable outputs and reduced context switching overhead.

faq.question: Who should be responsible for maintaining context?
faq.answer: Context maintenance should be collaborative. Include context reviews in pull requests and make updates a team responsibility rather than a single person's task. This ensures all stakeholders contribute to accurate documentation.
